skill.name: umap-learn
skill.description: UMAP dimensionality reduction. Fast nonlinear manifold learning for 2D/3D visualization, clustering preprocessing (HDBSCAN), supervised/parametric UMAP, for high-dimensional data.
skill.summary: UMAP dimensionality reduction. Fast nonlinear manifold learning for 2D/3D visualization, clustering ...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation with markdown-embedded Python examples. No executable scripts, network calls, file access, or environment variable access. Pure educational content about UMAP library usage.

content.value_statement: High-dimensional data is difficult to visualize and analyze. UMAP provides fast nonlinear dimensionality reduction that preserves both local and global structure for clear 2D/3D visualizations and effective clustering preprocessing.
actual_capabilities: Generate 2D and 3D embeddings for high-dimensional data visualization
Preprocess data for clustering algorithms like HDBSCAN
Apply supervised and semi-supervised dimension reduction with labels
Use parametric UMAP with neural networks for efficient new data transformation
Align related datasets with AlignedUMAP for temporal analysis
Preserve local density with DensMAP variant
limitations: Does not install umap-learn package automatically (requires user to install)
Does not execute code or generate visualizations directly
Does not handle data preprocessing (user must scale/normalize data first)
Does not provide built-in clustering (guides integration with HDBSCAN)

output_examples.input: Generate a UMAP embedding for my dataset
output: 2. Preprocess: scale data to comparable ranges

best_practices: Always standardize features with StandardScaler before applying UMAP for equal dimension weighting
Use n_neighbors=30 and n_components=5-10 for clustering preprocessing (not 2D visualization)
Set random_state for reproducible results in production pipelines
anti_patterns: Applying UMAP to unscaled data can produce misleading embeddings with artificially weighted features
Using default n_neighbors=15 for clustering creates fragmented artificial clusters
Expecting transform() to work well when test data distribution differs significantly from training data

faq.question: What is the difference between UMAP and t-SNE?
faq.answer: UMAP is faster, scales better to higher dimensions, and preserves more global structure while maintaining local neighborhood details.

faq.question: What parameters work best for clustering?
faq.answer: Use n_neighbors=30, min_dist=0.0, and n_components=5-10 instead of the visualization defaults.

faq.question: Can UMAP integrate with scikit-learn pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, UMAP follows scikit-learn conventions and works seamlessly in Pipeline with StandardScaler and classifiers.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using UMAP?
faq.answer: Yes, UMAP runs locally and does not send data to external services. All processing happens on your machine.

faq.question: Why are my clusters disconnected?
faq.answer: Increase n_neighbors to emphasize global structure. Low n_neighbors creates fragmented local neighborhoods.

faq.question: When should I use Parametric UMAP?
faq.answer: Use Parametric UMAP when you need efficient transformation of new data after training or want reconstruction capabilities.
